newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: Two suitors for CA seen equally serious.
newsitem.headline: Two suitors for CA seen equally serious.

text.p: Analysts found little to choose between Bank Austria and an EA-Generali group in the battle for Creditanstalt but said a challenge from supermarket mogul Karl Wlaschek was little more than an interesting distraction.
All three contenders submitted bids for the Austrian government's 70 percent of Creditanstalt ordinary voting shares ahead of a 0700 GMT deadline.
Analysts were divided on the merits of Bank Austria and the EA-Generali group as suitors but they were united in dismissing 79-year-old Wlaschek, former owner of the Billa supermarket chain.
"Wlaschek? I've never heard of him. I don't think this is very serious. He's probably going to be ruled out anyway because of his credentials," said an international analyst.

"Obviously it will be down to the value of the bids to a certain extent but I would have thought the government was unlikely to sell to a private individual," said Victoria Maxwell, Austria analyst at James Capel in London.
She said a beefed-up bid from the EA-Generali group, which includes savings bank Die Erste Oesterreichische SparCasse, Germany's Commerzbank and Banca Commerciale Italiana might take the day.
"Between them, (the members of the consortium) have got enough money to keep pushing up the bids," Maxwell said.

By selling traditionally conservative Creditanstalt to the EA-Generali group, Finance Minister Viktor Klima would also avoid the political headaches associated with a takeover by left-leaning Bank Austria, she added.
The EA-Generali consortium said it aimed to take control of 74 percent of the government's 19.9 million Creditanstalt ordinary voting shares and place the remainder over the market.
Union Bank of Switzerland, Commerzbank, Belgium's Bacob, Banca Commerciale and Die Erste (First Austrian) would help find the extra cash needed to the bid for the entire stake.

Bank Austria's offer was also worthy of serious consideration, analysts said. The nation's biggest bank is reportedly willing to pay 16 billion schillings, or 804 schillings a share, for its arch rival.
On Monday Creditanstalt ordinary shares closed at 737 schillings.
"(That scenario) certainly has the most potential but whether that potential will be realised is the question," said an international analyst.
"The Bank Austria bid certainly offers more in terms of restructuring potential. It is hard to see whether the consortium could achieve as much," said a banking analyst at Moody's in London.
Bank Austria's bid has aroused opposition among Creditanstalt employees, fearful for their jobs, and conservative politicians, reluctant to cede control of a powerbase.
A tie-up of the two banks would mean up to 5,000 job losses and a wave of branch closures, experts say.
A question mark over Bank Austria's ability to finance the deal and the EA-Generali group's ability to place 26 percent of the state's shares over the market worried some analysts.
But these concerns were not enough to give Wlaschek an edge, they concluded.
